Identifying Characteristics: Black or brownish-black shell with a variable number of round yellow spots—the spots may fade in old adults and sometimes adults can lack carapace spots altogether
Lower shell is yellow or orange with a black blotch covering a portion of each scute—sometimes black pigment can cover nearly the entire plastron
Head is mostly black, with a variable number of yellow spots—there is usually a large yellow or orange blotch on each side of the head
The upper legs and tail are black with a scattering of yellow spots and the lower legs and neck are orange to pink or salmon-red
Biology: Males and females can be told apart from birth—males have a tan chin, brown eyes, and a long, thick tail while females have a yellow chin, orange eyes, and a shorter tail than the male—in addition, the bottom shell of males is concave while it is either flat or convex in females and on average, females grow to be slightly larger than males and have more spots than males
Reach sexual maturity between 7 and 14 years of age
Nesting can occur from late May through June
Females usually lay one clutch of 1 to 8 eggs per year
Nesting females look for open, sunny locations that offer moist, but well-drained, soils
Nests dug with the hind feet
Eggs range from 2.5 to 3.4 cm long, are elliptical, and have thin, flexible shells
Incubation requires from 44 to 83 days—faster development at warmer temperatures
Majority of young emerge from nests in August or September but can also overwinter
Diet: Consumes plant material including aquatic vegetation, green algae, and sometimes wild cranberries
Animal food includes aquatic insect larvae, worms, slugs, millipedes, spiders, crustaceans, tadpoles, salamanders, and several kinds of small fish
Habitat: Swamps, bogs, fens, marshes, woodland streams, and wet pastures
Brackish streams that are influenced by tides and ditches, vernal pools, and sedge meadows
For a habitat to be sufficient for spotted turtle survival it must have areas of soft substrate and at least some aquatic vegetation
Shallow and slow moving waters with soft muddy soil, sedge tussocks, water lilies, sphagnum moss, and cattails
Can be found basking in patches of grass
Range: Southern Maine, Quebec, and Ontario, south along the eastern US to Florida in the east
Central Indiana and Ohio in the west
